title: Kenya: Policy Makers Blamed for Slow Legislation in Energy
text:
Kenya: You Are Dishonest, Raila Tells DP Ruto On Illicit Sugar 
"More than two-fifths (43 per cent) say governments are 'slow to legislate', thereby adding to uncertainty, with others emphasising the issue of low energy process or even going so far to say that policy uncertainty is undermining investment," the survey reads. 
TRANSPARENCY 
Kenya, Ghana, Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, South Africa are among the countries covered in the study which was conducted between November 2014 and March 2015. 
Chief executive officers and board members of the energy companies interviewed also noted lack of transparency in procurement of new power capacity and sufficient certainty on the governments backing for power purchase agreements (PPAs). 
In the case of Kenya, interviewees said that its power project viability requires clear long-term policy commitments on the amount of capacity that will be allocated to renewables and long-term off take agreements for projects. 
Kenya's electricity producer KenGen, for instance, is currently relying on the government, which holds 70 per cent stake, to hasten financing of its capital-intensive projects. 
ATTRACT FUNDING 
KenGen's Sh15 billion cash call has been delayed just because of government's indecisiveness. 
Also, the power producer is relying on the government policy on Private Public Partnerships to attract funding for its projects. 
The report comes at a time when Kenya is at the height of increasing its power generation capacity to 5,000 megawatts. 
Already, the government has signed 45 power purchase agreements initiated by State-owned Kenya Power. 
The latest agreements by Kenya Power were signed last week with Akiira Geothermal Limited for 70 megawatts and Kleen Energy Limited which is planning to add six megawatts. 
It is, however, uncertain if the firms have the ability to generate power in two years for connection to the national grid. Kenya
